awd_titl_txt: The Role of Neuronal Ionic Current Correlations and Level Sets in Network Activity
awd_abstract_narration:
Neurons generate the activity that drives behaviors thanks to electrical currents that flow across their membranes through several different but highly specific channels. These channels are formed by specialized proteins synthesized by each cell and embedded in their membranes. The activity that one can record from these cells (such as rhythmic oscillations) is expected to vary if the number of these channel-proteins varies. Yet, neurons of the same type have been observed to express extremely variable numbers of each channel-protein type, and thus extremely variable electrical currents flowing across their membranes, with relatively minimal effects on their activity (e.g., their oscillation frequency). Whether their existence ensures that the activity of these cells will be similar, and what the consequences for network function are, remains largely unclear. The general goal of this project is to examine what features of neuronal activity are regulated by electrical current correlations, whether these features of activity are propagated to the networks they form part of, and what universal principles or mechanisms these relationships obey. The results of this project are expected to have impact in various areas of mathematical biology, and the project will promote interdisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students through involvement in the research.

High variability in the levels of ionic conductance expressed by identical neurons have been observed in a number of preparations. In some of the same preparations, a tendency of some of the ionic conductances to co-vary has been identified. This co-variation appears as correlations of these currents in populations of neurons, which are thought to lead to the generation of very similar types of activity despite the variability of individual currents, in a sort of homeostatic scaling of these currents. This project will test the hypothesis that the existence of correlations among subsets of ionic currents determines a stable and robust neuronal activity, and that this effect propagates to the level of the networks. The features of activity affected by these correlations are expected to lie close to so-called level sets of activity for the oscillation attributes (e.g., frequency, amplitude, duty cycle). The mathematical concept of level sets has been applied to dynamical neuronal systems to a limited degree and only at the level of single neurons. The project team will investigate the mechanisms of generation of level sets, particularly related to the existence of ionic current correlations, in single neurons of a well-known neuronal network (the crustacean pyloric network). This project will (i) extend this to determine the consequences of their existence for network dynamics, (ii) determine if there are universal mechanisms, understandable in terms of classes of ionic current properties rather than individual current properties, that determine the emergence of level sets, and (iii) investigate what other factors determine the existence of level sets besides the amplitude of the conductances. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in a multidisciplinary investigation of the properties of neuronal systems, including computations, dynamical systems theory, and experiments.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at understanding the relationship between the high levels of variability in the expression of ion channels (the molecular building blocks that power the voltage changes that are the essence of neuronal function) observed in neurons and the seeming contradicting observation of nearly identical neuronal function (voltage changes) across neurons built with such highly variable building blocks. Using a reduced and simplified neuronal model (called lambda-omega model), we have characterized how the constancy of activity features in neurons built with different combinations of ion channels (called level sets) maps onto the activities of neuronal networks, and found rules that relate the activities between these two levels of neuronal complexity. This work was performed together with three students, one MS and two PhD students.
The concept of level sets that we explored in this project has led to an examination of a related problem, namely the issue of unidentifiability of parameters in a complex system. This problem arises when multiple sets of parameters can yield the same solution, such as observed along level sets. There are some trivial cases of such sets that can be described as simple scaling, but for the less trivial cases we have concluded that unambiguous parameter estimation can be achieved only under the condition that more independent features of activity are used to determine the parameters of the system than parameters that control the system. This is a major problem when complex systems such as biological cells and networks are involved since they are typically controlled by large numbers of parameters. This line of work will continue in future projects.
In an effort to characerize the dynamic nature of ion channel co-regulation and their effect on the physiology of neurons, we joined forces with a group at Johns Hopkins U, led by Dr. A. Kirkwood. We discovered that these correlations exist not only in invertebrates as know before, but also in mammals. We further discovered that channel co-regulation is subject to several forms of meta-regulation, in particular by the circadian rhythm that controls many bodily functions, including sleep, neuronal plasticity and learning. With another group led by Dr. A. Franci at UNAM, Mexico, we developed a theory that allows us to explain the changes in channel co-regulation in a novel manner. This involves the use of matrix theory, in particular the properties of Metzler matrices and high-dimensional multiplicity of the dominant eigenvalues. Intuitively such a matrix represents a network of molecular interactions that regulate the expression of ion channels in a cell. We have derived two forms of such a regulatory network (Metzler matrix) that can explain all the properties observed in neurons that express correlated levels of ion channel expression, namely correlations, robustness to perturbations, flexibility, insensitivity to initial conditions and modulatability. This work has derived in further theoretical and practical implications to be explored in a subsequent grant proposal and manuscripts. The work with Dr. Kirkwood has also resulted in unexpected observations unrelated to the current project which are the basis of another already submitted grant proposal.
This project has supported the training of several graduate and undergraduate students in mathematical biology and computational neuroscience. It has also impacted the materials and approaches the PIs use in their coursework and has generated new mathematical therory and several important national and international collaborations spawning several new projects.
